content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser." A private fund is an issuer that would be an investment company under the Investment Company Act of 1940 but for certain exceptions. A foreign private fund adviser is an investment adviser without a US place of business, with fewer than 15 US clients and assets under management. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser." A foreign private fund adviser is an investment adviser without a US place of business, with fewer than 15 US clients and assets under management of less than $25,000,000. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 does not act as an investment adviser in the United States or to any registered investment company under the Investment Company Act of 1940. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF PRIVATE ADVISER EXEMPTION; LIMITED EXEMPTION FOR FOREIGN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS; LIMITED INTRASTATE EXEMPTION. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. Additionally, a new category is added for advisers solely advising private funds. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. A new category is added for advisers solely advising private funds. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to authorize the Commission to require registered investment advisers to maintain records and file reports on private funds for investor protection and systemic risk assessment in consultation with the Federal Reserve System. The Commission, in consultation with the Federal Reserve System, is authorized to require registered investment advisers to provide reports on private funds for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. The records and reports of any private fund advised by a registered investment adviser will be considered the adviser's own records. Under this Act, records and reports of investment advisers must include information on assets under management, leverage, counterparty credit risk exposures, trading positions, practices, and other necessary information determined by the Commission in consultation with the Federal Reserve System. The Commission may require private fund advisers to report additional information deemed necessary for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. Different reporting requirements may be set based on the types or sizes of private funds advised. Maintenance of records is also mandated for investment advisers. Private fund advisers must adhere to different reporting requirements based on the types or sizes of private funds they advise. Investment advisers registered under this Act are obligated to maintain records of private funds for specified periods as prescribed by the Commission for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. These records are subject to periodic and special examinations. Investment advisers registered under this Act must allow the Commission to conduct periodic and special examinations of their private fund records. They are also required to provide copies or extracts of records upon request. The Commission is obligated to share information with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve. The Commission must provide the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve with all reports, documents, and information filed by investment advisers for assessing systemic risk of private funds. The information obtained must be kept confidential. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve must keep confidential all reports, documents, and information obtained from the Commission regarding private fund systemic risk assessment. Investment advisers must provide certain private fund information to investors, counterparties, and creditors as prescribed by the Commission for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. The Commission is not required to disclose any reports or information filed with them, except for specific circumstances outlined in the law. This includes sharing information with Congress, other federal agencies, self-regulatory organizations, or complying with court orders. The Commission is not obligated to disclose reports or information unless requested by authorized entities such as Congress, federal agencies, or in compliance with court orders. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to eliminate a disclosure provision and provide an exemption for venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements, with the requirement to maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. SEC. 7. EXEMPTION OF AND REPORTING BY CERTAIN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS. Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption from registration requirements for investment advisers of private funds with assets under management in the US of less than $150,000,000. These advisers must maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. The Commission requires investment advisers of mid-sized private funds to submit annual reports for investor protection. Regulations consider fund size, governance, and investment strategy to assess systemic risk and determine registration and examination procedures accordingly. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. Section 211 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to make rules and regulations based on factors like size, scope, business model, compensation scheme, and systemic risk potential. The Commission is granted authority to make rules and regulations based on factors like size, scope, business model, compensation scheme, and systemic risk potential. Different requirements can be prescribed for different classes of persons or matters, and different meanings can be ascribed to terms as necessary. The Commission, in consultation with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, must establish rules within 12 months of the Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009 for reports to be filed by investment advisers registered under both the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act. SEC. 9. GAO STUDY. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to assess the annual costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements under this Act. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. This Act and its amendments will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period from the enactment date. The Securities and Exchange Commission will establish rules allowing advisers to register before the deadline. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. The Commission will adjust dollar amount tests for inflation every 5 years. Adjustments not multiples of $1,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000.
